facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 116 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 116. of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 13, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 212 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 212, of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 Lala Ram Swaruup and five other family members sued Shikar Chand and his son for ejectment from shop in Qasba Chandausi, Bazar Waram.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1, Lala Ram Swaruup, and five other members of his family sued the two respondents, Shikar Chand and his son, for ejectment from the shop situated in Qasba Chandausi, Bazar Waram,

facts.text: Premises let out to respondents to conduct their shop on monthly rent with effect from April 11, 1952, for a year.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that the said premises had been let out to the respondents to companyduct their shop on a monthly rent with effect from the 11th April, 1952, for a year.

facts.text: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 (U.P. Act III of 1947) was in force at the time the suit was brought.

anchor.surface_text: At the time when the present suit was brought, the U.P.  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  U.P. Act III of 1947   hereinafter called the Act  was in force.

facts.text: Appellants applied for permission to District Magistrate, Moradabad under S.3(1) of the Act, which was refused.

anchor.surface_text: they had applied for permission-to the District Magistrate, Moradabad, under S. 3  1   of the Act that the said permission had been refused by him,

facts.text: Commissioner granted permission to appellants in revision under S.3(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: whereupon they had moved the Commissioner in his revisions jurisdiction under S. 3  2  of the Act and that the Commissioner had given them permission to file the suit.

facts.text: Suit No. 349 of 1954 filed on July 14, 1954 for ejectment and damages Rs. 35 per month from April 11, 1953 to July 11, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The suit  No. 349, of 1954  was filed on the 14th July, 1954. ... for use and occupation of the suit premises from 11th April, 1953 to 11th July, 1954 Rs. 35/- per month.

facts.text: Respondents resisted suit claiming non-joinder of parties, permission by Commissioner invalid, rent note inadmissible, notice under S.106 TP Act invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents resisted the claim made by the appelants on. several grounds. They urged that the suit was bad for number- joinder of necessary parties that the permission to sue granted to the appellants by the Commissioner was number valid in law that the rent numbere executed by them was number admissible in evidence and that the numberice given by the appellants under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act was also invalid in law.

facts.text: Munsif Chandausi decreed suit in favour of appellants on March 25, 1955 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge recorded findings in favour of the appellants on all the issues and decreed their suit with companyts on the 25th March, 1955.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to District Judge Moradabad in Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955, decree confirmed on June 2, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then preferred an appeal  Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955  in the Court of the District Judge, Moradabad, ... The learned District Judge rejected the respondents companytentions and companyfirmed the decree under appeal on the 2nd June, 1955.

facts.text: Second appeal No. 1106 of 1955 to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: That took the respondents to the High Court at Allahabad in second appeal  No. 1106 of 1955 .

facts.text: Single Judge of Allahabad High Court held permission invalid, suit incompetent, judgment on July 26, 1956, allowed leave for Letters Patent Appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge of the said High Court who heard this appeal, upheld the respondents companytention that the permission granted by the Commissioner under s. 3  3  of the Act was invalid in law and so, he came to the companyclusion that the appellants suit was incompetent. This judgment was delivered on the 26th July, 1956. The learned Judge, however, allowed the appellants leave to file a Letters Patent Appeal.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal heard by three Judges of High Court, majority held permission invalid, dismissed on September 13, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Appeal was placed before a larger Bench of three learned Judges of the High Court, ... Two of the learned Judges held that the said permission was invalid, whilst the third learned Judge held that it was valid. In accordance with the majority opinion the Letters Patent appeal.preferred by the appellants was dismissed on the 13th September, 1960.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and it is with the said certificate that this appeal has companye to this Court.

facts.text: Appellants needed premises for their own business.

anchor.surface_text: In their plaint, the appellants pleaded that they needed the premises in suit to carry on their own business in the shop,

facts.text: District Magistrate's permission required under S.3(1) of the Act for eviction suit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act imposes certain restrictions on the landlords right to eject his tenant from the premises to which the Act applies. ... a landlord can evict his tenant if he satisfies two companyditions. The first companydition is that he must obtain the permission of the District Magistrate to file such a suit

facts.text: Commissioner can revise District Magistrate's order if acted illegally, with material irregularity, or wrongly refused to act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 2  and  3  as they stood at the relevant time read thus - The party aggrieved by the order of District Magistrate granting or refusing to grant the permission referred to in sub- section  1  may, within 30days from the date of the order or the date on which it is companymuni- 5 57 cated to him, whichever is later, apply to the Commissioner to revise the order. The Commissioner shall, as far as may be, hear the application within six weeks from the date of its making, and, if he is satisfied -that the District Magistrate has acted illegally or with material irregularity or has wrongly refused to act,

facts.text: Appellants argued civil courts lack jurisdiction to question Commissioner's permission order due to S.3(4) and S.16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal, the first point which Mr. Goyal for the appellants has raised for our decision is that the companyrts below had numberjurisdiction to companysider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner. ... Section 3  4  provides that the order of the Commissioner under sub- section  3  shall subject to any order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, be final. Similarly, S. 16 provides that numberorder made under this Act by the State Government or the District Magistrate shall be called in question in any Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held civil courts jurisdiction excluded except where order is nullity, e.g., lack of jurisdiction, violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil companyrts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil companyrt goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the companyclusion that the impugned order is a nullity. ... Such a plea cannot, in our opinion, be excluded by reason of the provisions companytained in S. 3  4  and S. 16 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Commissioner's permission valid, not limited to jurisdictional errors like CPC S.115.

anchor.surface_text: The majority decision is that the jurisdiction companyferred on the Commissioner under s. 3 3  is exactly similar to the jurisdiction companyferred on the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. ... Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was number justified in introducing a-limitation pertaining to questions of jurisdiction in determining the scope of the width of the revisional-,visional power companyferred on the Commissioner by S. 3  3 .

facts.text: S.3(3) amended by Act 17 of 1954 to confer wider powers on Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, we may incidentally point out that by a subsequent amendment of s. 3 3 , the Legislature has made it clear that its intention is to companyfer wide jurisdiction on the Commissioner. The amendment in question has been introduced by Act 17 of 1954.

Section 3 of the Act imposes certain restrictions on the landlords right to eject his tenant from the premises to which the Act applies. Broadly stated, the effect of the provisions contained in S. 3 1  is that a landlord can evict his tenant if he satisfies two conditions. The first condition is that he must obtain the permission of the District Magistrate to file such a suit

concepts.interpretation: Requires landlord to obtain permission from District Magistrate before filing eviction suit, and prove one of seven grounds.

issues.text: Whether the courts below had jurisdiction to consider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner under the Act, given the provisions of Sections 3(4) and 16 excluding civil court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal, the first point which Mr. Goyal for the appellants has raised for our decision is that the courts below had no jurisdiction to consider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner.

issues.text: Whether the permission granted by the Commissioner was without jurisdiction and as such, a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which then calls for our decision in the present appeal is is the permission granted by the Commissioner without jurisdiction and as such, a nullity ?

issues.text: Whether the revisional jurisdiction conferred on the Commissioner under Section 3(3) of the Act is exactly similar to the jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, limited to jurisdictional errors.

anchor.surface_text: The majority decision is that the jurisdiction conferred on the Commissioner under s. 3 3  is exactly similar to the jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: Whether pleas going to the root of the matter, rendering the impugned order a nullity (such as violation of natural justice in quasi-judicial proceedings under Section 3), can be raised in a civil court despite the bar under Sections 3(4) and 16.

anchor.surface_text: the bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil courts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil court goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the conclusion that the impugned order is a nullity.

arguments.claim: courts below had no jurisdiction to consider validity of permission granted by Commissioner due to s.3(4) and s.16

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal, the first point which Mr. Goyal for the appellants has raised for our decision is that the courts below had no jurisdiction to consider the question about the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner. He contends that s. 3 of the Act provides a self-contained code for the grant of permission

court_response_anchor.surface_text: trate, be filed in any Civil Court against a tenant for his eviction from any accommodation, except on one or more of the following grounds. It is unn

arguments.court_reasoning: words of s.3(4) and s.16 clear and exclude jurisdiction; but bar cannot operate where plea shows impugned order is nullity

arguments.claim: civil courts jurisdiction excluded by s.3(4) and s.16 except where order is nullity

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Goyal is right in contending that the jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3 4  and s. 16. This conclusion, however, does not necessarily mean that the plea against the validity of the order passed by the District Magistrate, or the Commissioner, or the State Government, can never be raised in a civil court.

arguments.claim: proceedings under s.3 are quasi-judicial requiring natural justice; violation renders nullity challengeable in civil court

anchor.surface_text: if it is held that the proceedings before the appropriate. authorities contemplated by S. 3 are in the nature of quasi-judcial proceedings and they must be tried in accordance with the principles of natural justice,

arguments.claim: Commissioner power under s.3(3) wide, not analogous to or limited by CPC s.115; covers illegality, material irregularity, wrongly refused to act

anchor.surface_text: In construing the provision of s. 3 3 , one factor which is patent is that it ,does not refer to any considerations of jurisdiction at all... Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was number justified in introducing a-limitation pertaining to questions of jurisdiction

arguments.claim: legislative intent to confer wide jurisdiction on Commissioner confirmed by 1954 amendment to s.3(3) and wide s.7-F power

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may incidentally point out that by a subsequent amendment of s. 3 3 , the Legislature has made it clear that its intention is to confer wide jurisdiction on the Commissioner. The amendment in question has been introduced by Act 17 of 1954.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3(4) and s. 16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Goyal is right in contending that the jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s. 3 4  and s. 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of s.3(4) and s.16 clear and unambiguous; express exclusion in s.16, inescapable inference from s.3(4); special statutes can exclude civil jurisdiction if express or necessary implication; adequate alternative remedies provided.

holdings.text: The bar excluding civil courts' jurisdiction does not operate where the plea goes to the root of the matter and shows the impugned order is a nullity (e.g., lack of jurisdiction, violation of natural justice).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil courts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil court goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the conclusion that the impugned order is a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nullity pleas (wrong officer, extra-territorial, mandatory procedure violation, natural justice breach) render order void ab initio; cites precedents like Mask & Co., Kamala Mills; bar only covers merits/propriety, not fundamental invalidity.

holdings.text: Proceedings under S.3 are quasi-judicial and must comply with principles of natural justice; violation renders order a nullity challengeable in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: if it is held that the proceedings before the appropriate. authorities contemplated by S. 3 are in the nature of quasi-judcial proceedings and they must be tried in accordance with the principles of natural justice, and it is shown that in a given case, an order has been passed without notice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical/statutory notice mandatory; absent that, natural justice applies per Lala Shri Bhagwan; violation = nullity outside statutory bar.

holdings.text: Revisional jurisdiction of Commissioner under S.3(3) is not limited to jurisdictional errors as in CPC S.115; covers acting illegally, with material irregularity, or wrongly refusing to act.

anchor.surface_text: In construing the provision of s. 3 3 , one factor which is patent is that it ,does not refer to any considerations of jurisdiction at all... Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was number justified in introducing a-limitation pertaining to questions of jurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text unambiguous; three broad categories not centred on jurisdiction; DM normally has jurisdiction; wrongly refused to act covers errors; distinguishes CPC S.115.

holdings.text: Permission granted by Commissioner under S.3(3) is valid in law; High Court erred in holding it invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which then calls for our decision in the present appeal is is the permission granted by the Commissioner without jurisdiction and as such, a nullity ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No jurisdictional defect or nullity; Commissioner's wide power applies; respondents' plea only challenges merits, barred by s.3(4)/16.

holdings.text: Only pleas rendering order a nullity can be raised in civil court; other pleas challenging correctness/propriety barred by ss.3(4) and 16.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already emphasised, the only plea which can be raised before a civil court in relation to orders passed under the relevant provisions of the Act can be a plea which, if sustained, would render the order wholly invalid and as such, a nullity. No other plea can be raised, because all other pleas are barred by ss. 3 4  and 16 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates distinction between merits (barred) and nullity (allowed); consistent with precedents.

holdings.text: Subsequent amendment to S.3(3) by U.P. Act 17 of 1954 confirms legislative intent for wide Commissioner jurisdiction even under unamended provision.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may incidentally point out that by a subsequent amendment of s. 3 3 , the Legislature has made it clear that its intention is to confer wide jurisdiction on the Commissioner. The amendment in question has been introduced by Act 17 of 1954.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incidental observation; amendment explicit on correctness/legality/propriety; unamended already wide; s.7-F wide.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which then calls for our decision in the present appeal is is the permission granted by the Commissioner without jurisdiction and as such, a nullity ?

That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3 3  is invalid

anchor.surface_text: As we have already emphasised, the only plea which can be raised before a civil court in relation to orders passed under the relevant provisions of the Act can be a plea which, if sustained, would render the order wholly invalid and as such, a nullity. No other plea can be raised, because all other pleas are barred by ss. 3 4  and 16 of the Act.

That is why it must be held that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the permission granted by the Commissioner in exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 3 3  is invalid
